item.title: Simple Leitner Box
item.content:encoded:
Leitner Box Scheduler for physical flashcards.

This app is based on a 7-levels, 64-days calendar cycle of Leitner System.

Why should you use a digital scheduler?

Apart from taking a lot of time to prepare a physical schedule, the problem with traditional schedule arises when you forget to review, making you lose the place in the cycle. This app fixes that by showing both due and missed levels.

Features:

  • Start freshly from a new schedule
  • Continue from your existing schedule (must be based on 7-levels type)
  • Automatically calculate levels due each day and which level to do first
  • Automatically catch up with levels from missed days
  • Simple interface
  • No sign-up or sign-in required, your data is synced with your Apple ID

item.title: Simple Leitner Box
item.content:encoded:
This app was born on a night which I had to prepare for a few heavily memorization-based exams. It is based on the Leitner System. This system was proposed by Sebastian Leitner in the 1970s.

The idea of this is that in order to remember something, you have to review it at a certain interval, also known as "the forgetting curve". To combat this, Spaced-Repetition methods were invented.

Today, there are many variations of SRS implementation, integration, and software such as Anki, Rosetta Stone etc.

This app is based on the simple 7-levels, 64-days cycle schedule. Basically, you prepare a box by putting it in 7 sections (levels). Then you move the cards up or down the levels. Those levels are due on different days depend on the interval. Learn more about this on Wikipedia.

The problem is that creating a shedule is time consuming, and if you missed a day or forgot to track, you lose the mess up the schedule. That's why this app was made.

item.title: Achievy
item.content:encoded:
Alternative for physical study planner

Why this app was made

I wanted to make a study planner that is useful to both students and self-learners.

Like most students, I have to study a lot of materials for exams. The problem is, many exams have no content scope. This means you have to study everything the course provided. This can be very stressful for mainly two reasons. First, you feel anxious because you are not sure if your studying progress is on track. Second, you don't know that you are behind and you discover that too late. This anxiety double itself when you are graded 100% on the final exam, or if you have to take a professional exam that could be a once-in-a-lifetime chance.

This app focuses on creating a study plan for each material and simply forecast what's the progress will be at the end. The forecast feature has two main benefits. The first one is that you are motivated because you can visualize that every small progress count. Another one is that if you are behind schedule, you see it right away before it's too late.

As for self-learners, this app provides both flexibility and scope to study. When you want to learn something you're passionate about, you could feel like there are too many materials available on this planet. This app provide a structure to put you on track. Supported types of plans are: tracking amount, tracking chapters (book or video), and tracking comprehension percentage.

item.title: Achievy
item.description: Take charge of your studying progress.
item.content:encoded:
Take charge of your study life, achieve your study goal and feel in control.

Achievy suggests the minimum amount to study each day and visualizes what you will achieve on the deadline.

Features:

  • Let you create your own material to study - be it your book, online video course, etc.
  • Suggests minimum amount to study each day.
  • Tells you what the "new" tomorrow amount will be if you don't study today. With this, you have the flexibility to adjust your plan as life happens.

Great for:

  • Preparing for exams that require you to study a lot of materials in a limited time.
  • Self-study and make sure you are in control of your goal.

item.title: How to create multiple choices question on Anki
item.content:encoded:
How to create multiple choices question on Anki

Are you looking for a way to create multiple choices question on Anki?

This post shows how to do that. After this post, you will be able to create a card like this one.

The answer choices are randomized cloze hint.

First, make a copy of cloze type.

Firstly, go the the add card editor, press Type on the top left.

This will bring up a list of note type, then on the bottom left, press manage.

This will shows a the same list of existing note types but with buttons on the right. Press add to create new type.

This will bring up another list, this list allows you to create a copy of the chosen note type. We are going to copy the Cloze type. Press Add: Cloze then press OK.

Give the new note type a name.

Now, close all the pop ups, go back to the card editor and choose the newly created note type.

Then, bring up the fields list by pressing Fields

Edit it until it so that it looks like this

Edit the card template.

Back to the editor, press the cards button to bring up the template. Edit them to look like this.

Front

<h2>{{Topic}}</h2>

// This is where the text and choices will populate
<div id="choices" class="choice-holder">{{cloze:Text}}</div>

<script>

// select cloze element
var cloze = document.querySelectorAll(".cloze");
for (var i = 0; i < cloze.length; i++) {
	var hint = cloze[i].innerHTML
	
	// anki create additional bracket for cloze hint, we want them removed
	var newHint = hint.substring(1, hint.length - 1)

	cloze[i].textContent = "";

	if (newHint != "...")  {

		var list = ""
		// split the choices
		var arr = newHint.split("/");
	
		if (arr.length > 1) {
		    //shuffle the choices
		    shuffle(arr)
		}

		for (var j = 0; j < arr.length; j++) {
			// uncomment this line if you want the choices to be in separate lines
			//list = list + "<br>"
			list = list + "<span class=box>" + arr[j] + "</span>"
		}

		//put back the separated list to the card
		cloze[i].innerHTML = list
	} else {
	cloze[i].textContent += "_____ ";
	}
}

function shuffle (array) {
  var i = 0
	, j = 0
	, temp = null

  for (i = array.length - 1; i > 0; i -= 1) {
	j = Math.floor(Math.random() * (i + 1))
	temp = array[i]
	array[i] = array[j]
	array[j] = temp
  }
}

</script>

Back

<span id="answer" >{{cloze:Text}}</span>

<br><br>

<span id="hidden">{{cloze:Clozed Extra}}</span>

<div id="note" class="gray"></div>


<span class="gray"><br>{{Extra}}</span>

<script>
var holder = document.getElementById("note");
var hiddenContent = null
hiddenContent = document.getElementById("hidden");

if (hiddenContent != "") {
	var hiddenNote = document.querySelectorAll("#hidden .cloze");
	if (hiddenNote[0] != null) {
			holder.innerHTML = hiddenNote[0].innerHTML
	}
	
}

</script>


<script>

var clozes = document.querySelectorAll("#answer .cloze");
//document.getElementById("answer").innerHTML = "hello";

for (var i = 0; i < clozes.length; i++) {
	var temp = clozes[i].innerHTML;
	clozes[i].innerHTML =  '<span class="box green">' + temp + "</span>"
}


</script>

Style

.card {
 font-family: arial;
 font-size: 20px;
 text-align: left;
 color: black;
 background-color: white;
}

img {
	max-height: 140px
}

.hide {
	visibility: hidden;
	font-size: 0px;
}

.hide img{
	max-width: 0px;
}

.cloze {
 font-weight: bold;
 color: brown;
  visibility: visible;
}


.box {
  color: brown;
  display: inline-block;
  border-radius: 1.5em;
  padding: 4px 8px;
  border: solid 2px;
  margin: 5px;
  border-color: brown;
  background: pink;
	margin: 1.5px;
}

#hidden {
	display: none;
}

 .gray {
	color: gray;
}

.green {
	color: green;
	border-color: green;
	background-color: lightyellow;
}
